messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: "Manish P" <manish_the_friend@...>

> In our organisation we typically face problem of
> evaluating Testing effectiveness.
> The scenario is a bit different. In our organisation
> testing is evolving. Additionally there is a common
> problem of Devlopment Vs Testing arguments. In any
> regression round if a new bug comes in then the issue
> raised will be why this bug was not identified in
> previous round though it will be fixed later.

I have found that determining the reasons why a particular bug made it
through a test cycle need not be complex or formal beyond having a tester
(be they developer or dedicated tester) consider the cause of the bug and
add it to their test suite. As time progresses testing patterns evolve -
some may be general patterns that apply to most testing efforts, some may
only apply to a specific codebase - but I don't think to much consideration
should be given to post mortems of single bugs. Once a project or at least a
milestone is over, then maybe a given set of or class of bugs could be post
mortemed and both coding practices and test suites updated/adjusted.

> We thought over and looked into the possibility of
> checking effectiveness of testing.

I think such things as coverage metrics and overall number of bugs (or their
severity) will tell you more about test effectiveness than looking at
individual bugs that make it past a testing effort.

> As the process is still evolving Testing gets less amount of inputs ...
> in all sense - time, resource, documents, functional
> training... !

I am not sure what you are saying here. As processes evolve testing should
require less information input as the requirements become clearer and more
specific, but probably more resources (everybody, developers and testers
alike, underestimate resource allotments).

>
> My question is, in such constraints how one can
> measure and control the effectiveness of Testing?

I more or less covered it in my first post.

> This is typically for Manual Testing. The issue of
> Automated Testing remains apart ... :)
>

If you mean automated unit testing, then I don't think that is very much
different than manual unit testing in nature; the latter eventually becomes
that latter. If you mean system or GUI testing, then that is a different
issue and probably a bit off-topic for this list, but I have found that the
earlier you test (TDD and/or unit testing), the more manageable "manual"
testing (anything that can't be automated) becomes.

FWIW,
Lauren
